statement:
If $H$ is a subgroup of a finite group $G$ of index $p$, where $p$ is
the smallest prime dividing the order of $G$, then $H$ is normal in $G$.

Suppose $H\leq G$ with ${\vertG\vert}$ finite and ${\vertG:H\vert}=p$,
where $p$ is the smallest prime divisor of ${\vertG\vert}$, let $G$ act
on the set $L$ of left cosets of $H$ in $G$ by left , and let
$\varphi:G\rightarrow S_p$ be the by this action. Now, if
$g\in\ker\varphi$, then $gxH=xH$ for each $x\in G$, and in particular,
$gH=H$, whence $g\in H$. Thus $K=\ker\varphi$ is a normal subgroup of
$H$ (being contained in $H$ and normal in $G$). By the First Isomorphism
Theorem, $G/K$ is isomorphic to a subgroup of $S_p$, and consequently
${\vertG/K\vert}={\vertG:K\vert}$ must $p!$; moreover, any divisor of
${\vertG:K\vert}$ must also
${\vertG\vert}={\vertG:K\vert}{\vertK\vert}$, and because $p$ is the
smallest divisor of ${\vertG\vert}$ different from $1$, the only
possibilities are ${\vertG:K\vert}=p$ or ${\vertG:K\vert}=1$. But
${\vertG:K\vert}={\vertG:H\vert}{\vertH:K\vert}=p{\vertH:K\vert}\geq p$,
which ${\vertG:K\vert}=p$, and consequently ${\vertH:K\vert}=1$, so that
$H=K$, from which it follows that $H$ is normal in $G$.
names: normality of subgroups of prime index
